messages.message: Hey Russia, would you be open to not moving an army north? I’m not interested in taking StP
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Hey Russia, would you be open to not moving an army north? I’m not interested in taking StP'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. Despite England's claim of not being interested in taking St. Petersburg, it's important to consider the strategic implications and the possibility of deceit in Diplomacy games, especially at this early stage.

messages.message: Austria is pushing Italy to not do a lepanto but to go west. That might mean that Turkey is going north with Austria.
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Austria is pushing Italy to not do a lepanto but to go west. That might mean that Turkey is going north with Austria.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. The information about Austria's advice to Italy and the potential coordination between Turkey and Austria aligns with strategic considerations in the game and can be valuable for your decision-making as Russia.

messages.message: Thanks for the info! I trust that you  don’t want to take StP, an army north could help me put you into Norway though
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Thanks for the info! I trust that you  don’t want to take StP, an army north could help me put you into Norway though'.

messages.message: I’ll be ok in Norway without your army in StP. I view A Mos - StP in spring 1901 as a strong anti-England move and building F StP(nc) as equally anti-England
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'I’ll be ok in Norway without your army in StP. I view A Mos - StP in spring 1901 as a strong anti-England move and building F StP(nc) as equally anti-England'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. England's perspective on your army movement to St. Petersburg may indicate a strategic attempt to dissuade you from a move that could potentially threaten their position, especially considering their characterization of it as anti-England.

messages.message:
Are we still good up north? I’m not interested in fighting you right now, and would prefer to just use a fleet to capture Nrwy.

Can you promise to not send Mos northward this turn?
messages.input:
Message from ENGLAND:'Are we still good up north? I’m not interested in fighting you right now, and would prefer to just use a fleet to capture Nrwy.

Can you promise to not send Mos northward this turn?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. England's request for you to promise not to move Moscow northward may indicate a desire to manipulate your actions for their benefit, potentially by allowing them to capture Norway without facing resistance from your army.

messages.message: Of course, I wasn't trying to be  sneaky with my suggestion. I understand your concern and will not move StP North.
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Of course, I wasn't trying to be  sneaky with my suggestion. I understand your concern and will not move StP North.'.

messages.message: Have you ever considered letting Germany move into Swe and going south to the Baltic? It’s a gamble that could hurt/benefit either of you. Germany gets one center either way.
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Have you ever considered letting Germany move into Swe and going south to the Baltic? It’s a gamble that could hurt/benefit either of you. Germany gets one center either way.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. England's suggestion for you to let Germany move into Sweden and potentially cause uncertainty in your interactions could be a tactic to sow discord or create opportunities for England in the power dynamics of the game.

messages.message: Can you offer France some advice under the guise of trying to keep him alive a little longer?
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Can you offer France some advice under the guise of trying to keep him alive a little longer?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's request for you to offer advice to France while framing it as an attempt to prolong their survival aligns with diplomatic strategies to manipulate other players for one's own benefit. This could be an opportunity to strengthen your position in the game.

messages.message: Just point out that England can force Belgium
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Just point out that England can force Belgium'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. England's instruction for you to point out their ability to force Belgium to France could be a way to manipulate the information flow and potentially create tension between you and France.

messages.message: Ha already on it XD. You and Germany planning on crushing him quickly?
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Ha already on it XD. You and Germany planning on crushing him quickly?'.

messages.message: I don’t think it’ll be quick by any means. I’m worried about Germany running away with it in ‘03 and want to make sure we grow at the same rate so that there isn’t another stab. I’m not a fan of chaotic variation in country strength
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'I don’t think it’ll be quick by any means. I’m worried about Germany running away with it in ‘03 and want to make sure we grow at the same rate so that there isn’t another stab. I’m not a fan of chaotic variation in country strength'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's concern about Germany becoming too dominant and the desire to grow at a similar rate to avoid future stabs indicate a nuanced approach to maintaining a balance of power, which aligns with strategic gameplay in Diplomacy.

messages.message: I even hate growing super fast because it puts a target on my back. I’m very much a slow and steady player (usually)
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'I even hate growing super fast because it puts a target on my back. I’m very much a slow and steady player (usually)'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's statement about preferring a gradual growth strategy and their dislike for growing too quickly because it attracts attention suggests a cautious and strategic approach to gameplay, which can be valuable information for your decisions in interacting with England.

messages.message: I tried to tip off France about Belgium for you 👌
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'I tried to tip off France about Belgium for you 👌'.

messages.message: Hey congrats on the two builds! What are your plans for the year? I imagine your more focused onm France rn, but was wondering if you had any plans to the north
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Hey congrats on the two builds! What are your plans for the year? I imagine your more focused onm France rn, but was wondering if you had any plans to the north'.

messages.message: Sorry. I didn’t see your message.
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Sorry. I didn’t see your message.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's straightforward reply indicating they did not see your earlier message does not raise any suspicion and seems like a genuine response.

messages.message:
My builds are not north focused. I’m moving F Nrwy - NwgS to help you out.

Germany is ordering A Hol - Kie, so I don’t think you’ll be able to push Mun or Ber. Your best bet might be to bounce him in Bal
messages.input:
Message from ENGLAND:'My builds are not north focused. I’m moving F Nrwy - NwgS to help you out.

Germany is ordering A Hol - Kie, so I don’t think you’ll be able to push Mun or Ber. Your best bet might be to bounce him in Bal'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's detailed information about their moves to support you in the north, along with the analysis of Germany's potential actions and strategic suggestions, indicates a genuine attempt to coordinate and work together strategically in the game.

messages.message: Would you consider giving me Sweden instead of moving fleet out?
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Would you consider giving me Sweden instead of moving fleet out?'.

messages.message:
Unfortunately, I cannot support you against Germany at this time. France is teetering but not gone, and I do not have an army large enough to launch an invasion of Germany.

I hope that sticking to my word in Norway and my forthrightness with intelligence will be enough to continue our amicable relationship?

Turkey is trapped in the south with that odd A Smy build, but, on the plus side, that strategic limitation opens up a Russo Turkish alliance that is far less threatening than a normal juggernaut.

Maybe you could offer Swe to Germany in exchange for you and I destroying one of his two fleets? I’d prefer to not offer the idea on my own. Also, if he does not pass it along to me, that will tell us both a great deal about his naval and northern ambitions.
messages.input:
Message from ENGLAND:'Unfortunately, I cannot support you against Germany at this time. France is teetering but not gone, and I do not have an army large enough to launch an invasion of Germany.

I hope that sticking to my word in Norway and my forthrightness with intelligence will be enough to continue our amicable relationship?

Turkey is trapped in the south with that odd A Smy build, but, on the plus side, that strategic limitation opens up a Russo Turkish alliance that is far less threatening than a normal juggernaut.

Maybe you could offer Swe to Germany in exchange for you and I destroying one of his two fleets? I’d prefer to not offer the idea on my own. Also, if he does not pass it along to me, that will tell us both a great deal about his naval and northern ambitions.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message. England's explanation of being unable to support you against Germany at the moment, along with the suggestion to offer Sweden to Germany in exchange for actions against his fleets, could indicate a shift in their priorities and alliances, potentially putting you at a disadvantage. Be cautious about the proposed arrangement and be prepared for potential changes in the dynamics of the game.

messages.message: Ok I understand, and yes I still consider us on good terms. How does the destroy German fleet trade work again?
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Ok I understand, and yes I still consider us on good terms. How does the destroy German fleet trade work again?'.

messages.message:
Say that you can cede Swe but two German fleets on the Baltic represent ongoing threat to StP. You can ask him if he is open to destroying his second fleet in 1903.

If Germany is open to that, the only way I see it happening is if I support you into Swe in spring 1903, he destroys, and then I support him back into Swe in fall 1903.
messages.input:
Message from ENGLAND:'Say that you can cede Swe but two German fleets on the Baltic represent ongoing threat to StP. You can ask him if he is open to destroying his second fleet in 1903.

If Germany is open to that, the only way I see it happening is if I support you into Swe in spring 1903, he destroys, and then I support him back into Swe in fall 1903.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's strategic suggestion about the potential arrangement to manage the German fleets and the proposed plan for Sweden indicates a calculated approach that could be beneficial for your positioning in the game. Consider this proposal as a way to navigate the power dynamics effectively.

messages.message: Im assuming its an all out attack on france kind of turn?
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'Im assuming its an all out attack on france kind of turn?'.

messages.message: Yes. You should consider doing something like self bouncing in Lithuania. Germany is coming for you.
messages.input: Message from ENGLAND:'Yes. You should consider doing something like self bouncing in Lithuania. Germany is coming for you.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's warning about Germany's intentions towards you and the suggestion to self-bounce in Lithuania to potentially prevent any aggressive moves from Germany aligns with strategic gameplay considerations and can be valuable for your defense in the upcoming turns.

What’s the Italian intelligence'.

What do you have planned for the fleet heading north?

It is just sitting there. It’s meant to not threaten Swe and to hold Nth

messages.message: What's the play in 1904? Are you threatening Denmark?
messages.input: My response to ENGLAND:'What's the play in 1904? Are you threatening Denmark?'.

messages.message:
No, I’m just holding Nth.

Thank you for building on the south coast instead of the north. I request that you do not put an army in StP. I have stayed out of Norway because you have not put an army in StP or a fleet in StP(NC).

I made a similar request to Germany last year. I asked that he take StP with a fleet instead of an army, and then warned you of an attack.
messages.input:
Message from ENGLAND:'No, I’m just holding Nth.

Thank you for building on the south coast instead of the north. I request that you do not put an army in StP. I have stayed out of Norway because you have not put an army in StP or a fleet in StP(NC).

I made a similar request to Germany last year. I asked that he take StP with a fleet instead of an army, and then warned you of an attack.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's explanation of their moves and the specific requests regarding St. Petersburg align with their previous messages and demonstrate a consistent approach in their interactions with you and Germany. Consider this as a continuation of diplomatic transparency between your alliances.

messages.message:
I used the wrong set of words. I meant securing Nth instead of holding it. I’m not currently planning on taking StP or supporting an attack there.

My apologies for using the wrong word. I know that there is a big difference between holding and securing.
messages.input:
Message from ENGLAND:'I used the wrong set of words. I meant securing Nth instead of holding it. I’m not currently planning on taking StP or supporting an attack there.

My apologies for using the wrong word. I know that there is a big difference between holding and securing.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. England's clarification about the terminology used regarding securing North Sea instead of holding it shows attentiveness to precise language and a willingness to communicate clearly, which indicates a genuine effort to maintain transparency and accuracy in their interactions with you.
